philosophers.name: Anaxagoras of Clazomenae
philosophers.bio: Anaxagoras was a Greek mathematician famed as the first to introduce philosophy to the Athenians. He was imprisoned for claiming that the Sun was not a god and that the Moon reflected the Sun's light.

philosophers.name: Anaximander of Miletus
philosophers.bio: Anaximander of Miletus was a Greek scholar who first proposed that the sun, moon and planets revolved around the earth. He invented the gnomon of a sun-dial.

philosophers.name: Democritus
philosophers.bio: Democritus was an influential Ancient Greek pre-Socratic philosopher primarily remembered today for his formulation of an atomic theory of the universe.

philosophers.name: Empedocles
philosophers.bio: Empedocles is the source of the Classical idea that the universe is composed of four elements: Earth, Water, Air, and Fire.

philosophers.name: Thales
philosophers.bio: Many, most notably Aristotle, regard him as the first philosopher in the Greek tradition.

philosophers.name: Zeno of Elea
philosophers.bio: Zeno is well-known today for his paradoxes which sought to demonstrate the falseness of sensory information and the impossibility of change.
